Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Story:
It’s Thursday evening, and my phone buzzes with a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” I glance at the clock—7:00 p.m.—the time I always set aside for our weekly chat. They look forward to these calls, and so do I, usually. But tonight, my laptop screen is filled with error logs. QA just flagged a minor UI glitch that’s been popping up for some users. It’s not critical, and there’s a simple workaround, but my team lead wants it fixed before tomorrow’s release. I can already picture the Slack messages piling up if I don’t jump on it now.

My parents expect me to be present, to listen, to share. My team expects me to be responsive, to solve problems quickly. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my attention, each unwilling to wait. My finger hovers over the phone, my other hand poised above the keyboard, heart tugged in two directions as I wrestle with which part of me to disappoint tonight.
